comments.commentBody:
Little about the 2016 election leads me to think that historical models will have predictive power. We have not had a nominee like Mr. Trump -- one who cannot disqualify himself with foolish, ignorant, bigoted or rude remarks, one whom the media cannot stop showing clips of, one who has never held elective or military or public office, and one whom foreign dictators admire and endorse. We've also never had a major party nominee of my gender, and a raft of mental health professionals diagnosing the other major party nominee with a narcissistic personality disorder.

Here's my prediction: with the novelty of electing a woman to the presidency intriguing moderate Republicans and independents, and with the fear of electing a mentally unbalanced man haunting just about everyone, all the predictive models of the past are not very useful -- they all, after all, depend on both major party nominees being seen as minimally competent.

I think that the statistic about being on the wrong track needs to be clarified with why people think that, and not just ascribed to the performance of the president. Is it because of Congress, inequality, foreign policy? Without any understanding of people's reasoning it is not a very helpful piece of information.

I think the right-wrong direction question is basically useless.  I would say the country is headed in the wrong direction because the Republican congress will not do their job.  I would say also, Trump's campaign indicates that we are heading in the wrong direction in terms of our culture.  That is the reason I would vote for Hillary.  The fact that the economy did not grow by a huge number is not indicative of the wrong direction as far as I am concerned.  The point is the economy is growing as are job opportunities.  I wonder if people really prefer the boom-bust economic system vs. a slower growth rate?

I am a staunch Obama supporter, and would give him a third term if I could, but I still believe the country (and the world) are on the "wrong track," heading straight for a cliff comprised of global warming, sixth extinction, resource depletion, peak oil, acute water shortages and exponential population growth as far as the eye can see. The president's approval ratings are disconnected from "right-track-wrong-track" metrics simply because our being on the wrong track is a systemic reality, beyond the control of any one leader.

People who feel the country is going in the wrong direction should blame the republican majorities in congress and on the supreme court. The economic recovery would have happened sooner and its benefits been more widespread had the republicans not worked so hard to prevent it.  They resisted the stimulus bill and subsequent efforts to fund infrastructure projects when the recession was at its worst. And if wealthy interests enabled by Citizens United had not hijacked the government, the republicans in congress might have cared about the economic devastation their failed policies had caused millions of Americans.

You can keep arguing "right track, wrong track" till the cows come home but will no wiser till it is understood that all the ills of the current American presidential election process fatally suffers from the hugely influential crony capitalism.

The political class works to insulate itself by manipulating the apparatus of government. Crony capitalism is the part of a culture of self-dealing that leads to corruption, taxpayer abuse and the stunting of personal and economic freedom at every level of government. Its not about the rich and poor. It’s between the political class and everyone else who live under the thumb of the money, special interests and legal bribery that predetermines election outcomes in too many places to sustain a sense of confidence in the system.

Better question is what constitutes the wrong track. Are we on the wrong track because our nation's infrastructure is falling apart and our government isn't doing anything about it? Or the fact that we can't stop gun violence? Or we are on the wrong track because certain subsets of people aren't comfortable with change (even though they always claim it's time for change) and want to cling on to a version of America that now only exists in fiction? These  explanations, which would draw responses from voters across the spectrum, would tell me that there will be significantly more people saying that the country is on the wrong track vs. whether President Obama is popular or not.

I haven't read all the comments so maybe this is redundant. However, I was surprised Nate Cohn didn't point out the main flaw in this measure, which is that it conflates to different types of responses that lead to very different political outcomes. Some people may think the country's on the wrong track because there are too many immigrants and there's too much political correctness . They're likely to vote for Trump. Others may think it's on the wrong track because there's too much inequality, guns are too easily obtained, and everyone doesn't have access to health care. They voted for Sanders and most are likely to vote for Clinton (though some may not vote at all, may vote for s third party candidate, or may even vote for Trump). Without disaggregating the reasons why people think the way they do the measure is likely to have little predictive value for election outcomes.

I'll note in passing that a similar problem has bedeviled polling on the Affordable Care Act. Some don't like it because it's government overreach, others because it's not single-payer. While both groups may agree the ACA has failed the political consequences of that belief are very different, though both would agree that from their perspective the country is on the wrong track, whatever that means to them.

A couple of observations: first, we are currently a country inhabited by several generations of people, a lot of whom haven't seen "bad". The folks who lived through World War I, the Great Depression, the dust bowl, and World War II are rapidly dwindling in number. Second, we expect too much from our government. Many of us (including me) need to pay more attention to being better people, minding our own business, and thinking more about contributing than about benefitting. Finally, if we want our Federal government to get back on track, stop electing folks to Congress who think it is OK to put party politics and selfish goals ahead their constitutional responsibilities.

The mood in the country and the often-written about divisions have been created by the media and those who would profit from those creations.  For the Murdockian media operation, it's just good business to create hatred, fear and divisions because it draws the fearful to consume more of what feeds their fears.  And it feels good to the insecure to be able to blame someone else for their pain, or so it seems.  The wealthy and their political submissives use the division to diminish the democracy in favor of their oligarchy while lining their own pockets with the leavings of those financially destroyed in the process. The media provides the distraction of the "poorly educated" (the love of trumps' life) by promoting non-existent issues disguised as moral or ethical values, e.g., the war on christmas. All to say that the mood of the country is a creation rather than a knowledge-based reason to buy into the mood.

Right track wrong track is too broad a brush. The President doesn't affect your cable/phone company, your insurance company or big pharma screwing consumers. I suggest that the right track wrong track numbers be compared to the approval ratings of the 'best' Congress that money does buy.

replies.commentBody:
Agreed. The question assumes agreement on what defines "track." According to whom? The question becomes meaningless if "track" is totally relative.

If you said the country is "going to the dogs," it might imply a an elite point of view by people who are not "the dogs." Or if you said it was "going to hell in a hand basket," there is a sense of completely falling apart, of entropy.

"Right track/wrong track" is too binary a choice, implying only one path to a destination. The word "track" gives an image of a train-track, which is always fixed, with fixed places where the train can switch tracks. But in reality, there are often many paths to a goal, and they are not always well-trod, and just because one is not on a particular path does not mean one will not meet the goal.

The question "right track/wrong track" contains inherent illogic. Like the child in the children's book, "Harold and the Purple Crayon," the path we are on is of our own designing--the future is our own creation, and we are not following a predetermined "track" as we are each bushwhacking a trail.

The right track, wrong track question by pollsters just polarizes politics even further. Republicans think that the right track would be even more conservative, while Democrats believe that the right track is even more liberal policies.

Will someone please get rid of this uninterpretable question and ask some specific questions about what is really most important to voters. And find out how many voters are truly one issue voters (e.g. pro-life, pro-choice) for whom any of these other very important issues are irrelevant to their vote.

For several decades, pollsters used to track Americans on what worried them the most. Their answer: "Crime." But when the same worriers were asked, "Are you worried about crime in your neighborhood?" Their answer this time: "No."
What could explain the vast gulf in respondents' opinions on crime and violence? The answer: the relentless sensational informercialization of vilolent crimes when they turn on their TV. If pollsters are to ask, "Are better off today than in 2008-2009?" and "Do you think the country is moving in the wrong direction?", you will most likely get an optimistic response to the first question and a pessimistic one to the second. With the proliferation of mass media gunning for the bottom line (e.g. "Trump may not be good for America, but he is great for CBS," says CBS executive), is it any surprise that the mood about the country is downright bleak even though the sentiments of Americans about their own lives are rather upbeat.
